entry.title: Re: Incorrect Pricing Condition Assigned During EDI Sales...
entry.content:
When you create an inbound ORDERS IDoc via the SAP_COM_0223 C4C‚Äêto-S/4HANA communication arrangement, the system still runs its standard pricing determination exactly as if you‚Äôd typed the order in manually. In your case:

  • ZPR0 is defined in your pricing procedure as the ‚Äúcorrect‚Äù base-price condition for EDI
  • ZPS0 is also in your procedure (typically as the intercompany price)

Because of the way your access sequence and condition records are set up, the system never finds a valid ZPR0 record for your customer-material-plant combination and simply continues down the search sequence until it locates a ZPS0 record.

Confirm Which Pricing Procedure and Access Sequence are in Play. This you can do by running a pricing trace on the order in Fiori (e.g. ‚ÄúTrace Pricing Determination‚Äù) or display the order and, in the Item ‚Üí Conditions tab, click Analysis.
You‚Äôll see exactly which access steps (condition tables) were hit and why ZPR0 failed (no record) and ZPS0 succeeded.

Check and maintain your ZPR0 Condition Records by going to VK13 to verify that you actually have a valid ZPR0 record for that combination of sales org / dist. channel / customer / material / plant. ‚Äì If no record exists, create one in VK11. As soon as a ZPR0 record is found, the access sequence will pick it up first (assuming it‚Äôs higher in the sequence than ZPS0

  • Review your Access Sequence Configuration in SPRO (or the equivalent Fiori apps), go to Sales and Distribution ‚Üí Basic Functions ‚Üí Pricing ‚Üí Access Sequences ‚Üí ‚ÄúDefine Access Sequences.‚Äù
  • Find the access sequence used by your base‚Äêprice condition type.
  • Ensure the condition table for ZPR0 sits above the table for ZPS0 ‚Äî and that the Exclusive flag is set so the search stops once a ZPR0 record is found.

Finally, validate Pricing Procedure assignment for EDI Orders. Even though the inbound IDoc uses standard order type ORDERS, double-check:

Sales Document Type (OVKK/VOV8): Verify the pricing procedure assigned to the EDI order type hasn‚Äôt been altered to point to an intercompany-only procedure.
Customer-Pricing Procedure Determination: Confirm your customer classification ‚Üí pricing procedure mapping doesn‚Äôt default to an ‚Äúintercompany‚Äù procedure under certain customer groups.

If a separate pricing procedure is being determined (one that lists ZPS0 as the first base price), you‚Äôll need to adjust that determination rule so the same procedure with ZPR0 is used instead.

entry.title: Case Management: Configuring the Input Step in the Case Flow
entry.content:
Input step in guided case flow is designed to render the configured fields directly within the flow, allowing agents to update them without navigating away from the guided process. This avoids the need to search for fields in the case details screen or make multiple clicks to reach them, thereby enabling faster and more efficient case handling.

Prerequisites:

Draft case type version

Configuration:

1. Open DRAFT case type version in detail view.

2. Navigate to Case Flow tab.

3. Click on Create Step button which shows the list of step types that can be created.

4. Click on Input step type from the list which open up a main view in a seperate tab.

5. Enter the mandatory field name, optionally provide the display ID, help text and mandatory step flag. If mandatory flag is set, the phase can be completed only when the step is completed. 

 6. Optionally, create preconditions for the Input step. If set, the fields in the form become editable, and the step can be completed only when these preconditions are met. To create pre-conditions, click on Create Pre-conditions button.

 7. Set the pre-conditions and click on Save.

 8. Newly created pre-conditions will appear in the Pre-conditions section of the right panel. Edit and delete options are available for the pre-condition. Click the respective button to perform the action.

 9. Add all the relevant fields. You can either click the plus (+) button to pull the field into the middle panel as a new row, or drag and drop it into the desired row. A maximum of three fields can be added to a row, and any excess fields will be placed in the next row.

 10. Click on Save to create the Input step.

 11. Close the Input step tab and navigate to Case Template tab. The newly created Input step will be added as the last step in the phase.

 12. Optionally, rearrange the step using the drag handle.

13. Edit and delete options are available for the step. Click the respective button to perform the action.

14. Finally, click on Activate button to activate the case type version.

 This completes the Input step configuration.

Input Step in action:

1. Create a case with the newly activated case type, and open it in detail view. Enter values for all form fields, then click Save to apply the changes.

 2. Click on Set Step to Done button to complete the step.

Summary:

In summary, the Input step streamlines case handling by placing essential fields directly within the guided case flow. By reducing navigation and clicks, it empowers agents to work more quickly and efficiently, ensuring a smoother experience for both agents and customers.

entry.title: Re: SAP Enable Now ‚Äì Different Workflows for Original and...
entry.content:
Hi @Solution_Master 

Thank you for your detailed questions. Let me walk you throug it.

Unfortunately, it is not possible to manage different workflows within a single workarea in SAP Enable Now. The system only allows you to assign one workflow per workarea. This means you cannot directly have distinct workflows for original content creation and translations within the same work area based on you object type or status. However, to enable you keep everything organized within a single project, I would suggest we look at some best practice

An option would be to use Separate Workareas for Different Workflow needs and here is your best approach:

  • Maintain your original content creation workflow in one workarea
  • Create a separate workarea dedicated to translated content, where you can assign the translation-specific workflow.
  • Although this requires switching workareas, it keeps workflows clean and tailored to the process stage.

A second option would be to leverage Object Metadata and Filters to Manage Content by

  • Using metadata tags or custom properties to distinguish original versus translated content.
  • This will help you in managing, filtering, and reporting within each workarea, so users are guided on which content belongs to which process.

Another option would be to automate Content Movement Between Workareas:

  • Automate the duplication or import of your original content into the desired translation workarea using SAP Enable Now‚Äôs APIs or scheduled tasks. This will ensure streamlining your work.
  • This way, translators always work on the correct copy linked to the translation workflow without manual intervention.

You can also consider Workflow Extensions or Customizations:

  • Please note that while the out-of-the-box Enable Now only supports one workflow per workarea, check if your environment supports workflow extensions or custom scripting that could change workflow behaviour based on object attributes.
  • This is often limited and depends on your system version and support status.

Finally, you have the option to coordinate Publishing and Version Management:

  • Considering your original workflow automates publishing, make sure the translated content publishing is coordinated separately to avoid conflicts or overwriting.

To summarize, the current design expects one workflow per workarea. To manage multiple workflows in the same project, best practice is to split original and translation content into separate workareas, each with appropriate workflows, while using metadata and automation to keep the content aligned.

If you haven‚Äôt already, I recommend reaching out to SAP Enable Now support for further guidance.

I hope this provides some clarity. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

If you find my response helpful, kindly accept the answer and award a Kudos to this post. Your support is appreciated.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: How to declare both quantity and billing percentage i...
entry.content:
Milestone Billing and Progress Billing are mutually exclusive.  If the client wants to bill a % of the total contract based on a milestone achievement then how does the actual quantity fit into the amount to be billed?  A typical ECO company will bill using Progress Billing rather than Milestone Billing.  For Progress Billing you list the Schedule of Values on the Sales Order and every month invoice for a partial quantity that was achieved during the month.  The unit of measure on each Sales Order Line Item can be different, for example, for Cement you can use Tons, then for Site Clearing you can use %.  

Hope this helps.

entry.title: SAP RISE - Six Integration Patterns You‚Äôll Face
entry.content:
In one of my previous blogs Why SAP ISA-M Still Matters ‚Äì A Strategic Foundation for Modern Integration I have given some insights in which projects & situations I am currently using ISA-M to define my Integration patterns.  What should be more strategic then RISE nowadays?  

 

üß≠ The Integration Architect‚Äôs Dilemma in RISE Projects

It usually starts with excitement ‚Äî ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre moving to RISE!‚Äù. But as the Integration Architect, you feel a shift in the room once you ask:

‚ÄúHow will your business-critical integrations survive the move?‚Äù

‚ÄúHow will our Integration Patterns change in a Private Cloud Environment?‚Äù

‚ÄúDo we have to an option to be part of this modernization?‚Äù

In too many RISE conversations, integration is not part of initial phases , but everything depends on it. Whether you‚Äôre facing direct system-to-system integrations, legacy SAP PO platforms, or the modernization path toward Integration Suite and AEM: you need clarity.

 

Let‚Äôs talk about the 6 most common integration scenarios I encounter in RISE projects ‚Äî and let‚Äôs do a deep dive into one of them.

üìåContext: What Makes RISE Integration Different?

ISA-M allows us to talk in Integration patterns ‚Äî proven, repeatable ways to connect cloud, on-prem, and hybrid landscapes.

Draw your Integration landscape abstract as below and repeat the same for all Integration Domains and Integration Patterns, maybe Integration Styles. We focus on the common Process Integration patterns which often are.

üîç Scenario 1: On-Premise to On-Premise (e.g., existing ECC system ‚Üí S/4, within same on-prem datacenter)

üí¨ Comment:
This is often the existing baseline. When the customers still host their systems locally. No RISE adaption in this case

üîç Scenario 2: Private Cloud to Private Cloud (e.g., S/4 to S/4 Integration, within same RISE datacenter)

 

üîßTechnology in use:

  • SAP Integration Suite, Edge Cell on a Private Cloud hyperscaler, such as Azure or AWS
  • VPN or direct peering within same hyperscaler
  • Azure VNet Peering, AWS VPC Peering, or similar as secure tunnel
  • Usage of transactions and APIM Management operations

üîç Scenario 3: Private Cloud to Public Cloud (RISE workload connects to SaaS like SuccessFactors)

üí¨ Comment:

For hybrid Integration SAP Integration Suite could be used as natural entry point

üîç Scenario 4: Public Cloud to Public Cloud (e.g., SuccessFactors ‚Üî Ariba or Salesforce ‚Üî S/4 in RISE)

üí¨ Comment:
This is a modernization sweet spot. Cloud-native to cloud-native with no concrete RISE touchpoints.

üîç Scenario 5: On-Premise to Public Cloud

üí¨ Comment:
This is often the existing baseline. When the customers still host their backend systems locally but use SaaS applications for certain LoBs. No RISE adaption in this case

üîç Scenario 6: On-Premise to Private Cloud (e.g., ECC ‚Üí RISE in Azure, hybrid operation)

üí¨ Comment:
This hybrid pattern is very common in staged RISE transitions. Customers keep some systems on-prem while moving others (‚Äúearly adaptors) into RISE.

 

üîßModernization Reality Check

Most customers do one of three things:

  1. Move PO Interfaces to SAP Integration Suite, Cloud Integration  and SAP Integration Suite, Edge Cell  
  2. Modernize to SAP Advanced Event Mesh
  3. Use more featreus of the SAP Integration Suite, such as API Managmenet

So here‚Äôs what I recommend to every architect:

  • Audit your interface and integration technologies before RISE.
  • Classify interfaces using along the patterns in this blog.
  • Decide per pattern: Keep, Modernize, or Sunset.
  • Actively design your new integration landscape ‚Äî don‚Äôt wait for someone else to.

 

üìû Let‚Äôs Build Smarter RISE Integrations

I‚Äôve worked on numerous RISE integration journeys and built a reference architecture library covering each scenario. If you want to see the diagrams, dig into patterns, or compare your setup ‚Äî I‚Äôm happy to help.

Ping us on SAP Integration Modernization <integration.modernization@sap.com>

entry.title: Display item of content page on master page in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud
entry.content:
Displaying a Text Field/Value from the Content Form on the Master Page in Adobe Forms.
Sometimes it can be tricky to display a field from the content page on the master page in Adobe Forms, because the master page does not contain any XML structure in the Data View (except for elements like the logo and footer). The master page does not have direct access to invoice, billing, or other master data.

Assumption: You have already created both a master form template and a content form template according to your business needs.

In this example, I have created:

  • Content form template: YY1_CINV_BILL_BE

  • Master form template: YY1_INVOICE_MASTER_FORM

Scenario

We need to print the invoice number on the master form template (instead of the content form template) because the requirement is to show the invoice number on every page of the PDF output.


Step 1: Download the templates

Download both the content form template and the master form template. After downloading, extract the XDP files and open the master form template in Adobe LiveCycle Designer.

You will notice that the DataConnection Node does not contain the invoice number, because it is part of the content form data. 

 

Now open the content form in Adobe LiveCycle Designer. Here, you can see that the invoice number is available in the content form ‚Äî but our requirement is to also display it on the master form.

Step 2: Bind the invoice number in the content form
Add a Text Field (name it InvoiceNumber) on the content form and bind it to the correct XML node for the invoice number.

Step 3: Create a hidden subform: 

If you want the invoice number to appear only on the master page and not on the content page, create a hidden subform.

  • Set the subform‚Äôs visibility to hidden.

  • Drag the InvoiceNumber text field into this hidden subform.

If you also want the invoice number on the content form, you can skip creating the hidden subform.

Step 4: Add the text field in the master form

Open the master form template in Adobe LiveCycle Designer and add a Text Field (also named InvoiceNumber).

In this example, I have added the field to both mst1 and mst2, since the invoice number must appear on both master pages.

Step 5: Write JavaScript to access content form data
Select the textField of the Master Form Template and then write one Javascript code in order to access the data of content form. The Javscript code is written in the Initialize event of the InvoiceNumber textField.

The path (Form.HeaderSubform.HiddenSubform.InvoiceNumber.rawValue) comes from inspecting the content form structure. We simply reference the rawValue of that node.

Step 6: Upload and test

Once the changes are complete in both the content form and the master form:

  1. Save the forms.

  2. Upload them to the public cloud using the Maintain Form Templates app.

 



Finally, test your invoice PDF using the Manage Invoicing Document app. You will now be able to see the invoice number printed on the left side of every master page.
Please let me know if you have any other solution for this requirement.
Happy Learning !!


Thanks,
Shubham

Entre os pilares centrais da reforma est√£o:

  • Simplifica√ß√£o de procedimentos: redu√ß√£o de burocracia e unifica√ß√£o de regras.

  • Fiscaliza√ß√£o em tempo real: seguindo o modelo j√° visto no Imposto de Renda pessoa f√≠sica, empresas ter√£o suas informa√ß√µes validadas automaticamente.

entry.content:

*** Todas as palestras aqui ***

Foram explorados cinco pilares t√©cnicos da solu√ß√£o:

entry.title: Re: Looking for Real-World Scenarios for Using Multiple C...
entry.content:
Hello @malik_khoumari 

Multiple Cycle Maintenance Plans in SAP PM are most effective when an asset requires different tasks at various intervals, but you want them managed under a single plan.

 Examples include below;

  • Monthly inspections, quarterly oil analyses, yearly overhauls (on the same equipment).
  • Legal inspections every 3 years plus annual safety checks.
  • Combining time- and usage-based tasks, such as every 500 hours and every 6 months.

The benefit is that one plan reduces administration and ensures coordinated scheduling.

Creating and Scheduling a Multiple Counter Plan-SAP Learning

With kind regards

Chuma

entry.title: Re: Need Clarification on the Role of SAP CS in the Conte...
entry.content:
Hello @malik_khoumari 

SAP CS (Customer Service) is used to manage after-sales service processes related to technical objects from SAP PM, which SAP SD alone cannot handle.

CS allows you to create service notifications and service orders linked to equipment or functional locations, manage warranties and service contracts, dispatch field technicians, and record actual labour and material costs.

The commercial aspects, such as pricing and invoicing, are still managed through SD, but CS ensures that the technical implementation is fully coordinated.

Typical scenarios where CS is essential include servicing machinery under warranty or long-term contracts, utilities maintaining customer-installed equipment, and medical device companies performing regulated maintenance with full compliance traceability.

In these cases, CS connects technical service delivery (PM) with commercial processing (SD), providing a unified process that addresses both operational and customer-facing needs.

Integrating PSM with SAP SuccessFactors

With regards

Chuma

entry.title: Negative Posting on Internal Order After Asset Capitalization ‚Äî Is This Expected Behavior?
entry.content:
Hello everyone,

I'm facing a situation related to asset capitalization in SAP ECC and would appreciate your insights.

üîπ Context:

  • Acquisition costs are posted directly to an Asset Under Construction (AUC) using account assignment category A (Asset).

  • At the same time, an internal order is assigned in the asset master record, which results in automatic CO postings of the same costs to the internal order.

  • The internal order is used to track costs for multiple assets, but only one asset is being capitalized at this stage.

üîπ Issue:
When I capitalize a single asset, SAP generates a negative posting on the internal order in CO.
This increases the available budget of the order, as if the cost is being "refunded".

üîπ Questions:

  1. Is this a standard and expected behavior in SAP?

  2. Why does asset capitalization (which should only affect AUC and final asset accounts) result in a CO posting on the internal order?

  3. Is there any way to filter out or exclude these negative postings in reports like S_ALR_87013019, to avoid misinterpreting the available balance?

  4. What would be the best practice in this kind of setup (direct posting to AUC + internal order in asset master)?

Thanks in advance for your help ‚Äî any documentation, technical explanation, or experience sharing would be greatly appreciated!

Best regards,

Mohamed

entry.title: Posting the accruals to the employee's time account as on when he worked for certain number of days.
entry.content:
We have a client requirement where we would need to post the accrual balance of 1 if the employee's working days count is 13 per month and the accrual balance of 2 if the employee's working days count is 21 or more in a month. I am storing the required count in the Time collector. However, the challenge is currently we are posting it in the accruable end date which is month end. However, the expectation from the client is to post the balance in the account whenever the employee has accrued the count of 13.

For example, if the employee has completed 13 working days in 17th day of the calendar month, he should get the balance of 1 in the 17th day itself and not on last day of the month. Can anyone let me know if any of you handled similar scenario and the best way to handle this around.

Current configuration. 

Time type , time account types are created. Time account type runs with monthly frequency. Working days collected in monthly Time collector and used to derive the accruals. Currently the job is running and the balance are posted in the last day of the month. 

Any inputs here would be very helpful.

entry.title: Integrating SAP SuccessFactors with SAP Build Process Automation via SAP Cloud Application Event Hub
entry.content:
Overview

SAP Build Process Automation is a low-code/no-code platform that enables users to automate business processes and tasks using visual drag-and-drop tools. It combines workflow automation, robotic process automation (RPA), and embedded AI capabilities to streamline processes and improve efficiency. 

SAP Cloud Application Event Hub offers a flexible solution to distribute business events across the SAP cloud landscape. This service supports SAP's strategic event-driven architecture initiative to create a well-defined, easily consumable and extensible ecosystem for exchanging SAP business events.

We are using the Personal Data Collection scenario as a use case for this blog. In SAP SuccessFactors Onboarding, the "Personal Data Collection" event refers to the process where new hires provide their personal details during the onboarding process. This step allows new hires to validate and, in some cases, update information pre-populated from the recruiting system. The event is triggered when a new hire accesses the "Provide Personal Details" section within the onboarding checklist. Read here for more details.

This blog walks through setting up integration between SAP SuccessFactors, SAP Build Process Automation(SBPA) and SAP Cloud Application Event Hub. With this setup, events like onboarding process step in SuccessFactors can trigger workflows in SBPA‚Äîenabling truly event-driven business automation. For more information on Success Factors events in Business Accelerator Hub read here.

The integration support was released from SAP Build in Q2 2025. For more details refer to the YouTube video Whats New in SAP Build ‚Äì Q2 2025 Highlights and Blog What‚Äôs New in SAP Build Q2 2025 - Release Highlights.

Note : Integration of SAP Build Process Automation with SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud Edition and SAP S/4HANA Private Cloud Edition is also available with Event Mesh and Advanced Event Mesh. Here are the reference blogs Event Mesh and SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud Setup for SAP Build Process Automation and Configure SAP Enterprise Messaging for SAP S/4HANA On-Premise 2020 via Service Key.

Prerequisites

Before you begin, make sure the following are available:

    • SAP BTP Global and Subaccount Account access as administrator
    • Check that the Active BTP Subaccount has SAP Build Process Automation Subscription for standard plan.

    • Valid SAP SuccessFactors CLD Tenant ID 

Step 1: Set Up Entitlements & Subscriptions

In this step we will setup the required entitlements and subscriptions. We will add "SAP Cloud Application Event Hub" subscription to BTP Subaccount if not already added.

Go to BTP Subaccount -> Entitlements -> Edit

Click on "Add Service Plans"

Search the services with keyword "event" and select "SAP Cloud Application Hub" service , then choose the service plan "standard" and click on "Add 1 Service Plan"

 Click Save.

The SAP Cloud Application Event Hub Service is added in sometime. This can be verified also from the BTP Subaccount -> "Services" - > "Service Marketplace" -> SAP Cloud Application Event Hub tile.

Create a new Subscription by clicking on the "SAP Cloud Application Event Hub" tile -> Create button.

Select the Service ‚ÄúSAP Cloud Application Event Hub‚Äù and Plan ‚Äústandard‚Äù and click on Create.

The subscription will be created in sometime. Click on ‚ÄúView Subscription‚Äù.

 In the BTP Subaccount ‚ÄúInstances and Subscriptions‚Äù -> Note that ‚ÄúSAP Cloud Application Event Hub‚Äù subscription is added with status as subscribed.

    • Add all the roles for the user for enterprise messaging. Refer to the details here.

Step 2: Register Your SuccessFactors System

In this step we will register the SuccessFactors system with the SAP BTP Subaccount. This step is needed to be able to discover events based on the connected system in the SAP Build. It enables SAP Cloud Application Event Hub to discover and communicate with your SFSF system.

    • Go to Systems in System Landscape in BTP Global Account
    • Switch to Service Owner View
    • Click on ‚ÄúAdd System‚Äù.
      • Select System Type as Success Factors
      • Enter a valid system name or your CLD Tenant ID from SuccessFactors
      • Click on Add

    • Confirm the system appears in the list

Step 3: Create Eventing Formation

Eventing between SAP Cloud systems enables decoupled communication by exchanging events between applications. This approach allows systems to react to changes in other systems without direct dependencies, promoting flexibility and scalability. 

    •  Navigate to Global Account ‚Üí System Landscape ‚Üí Formations
    • In Customer View -> Click Create Formation

    • Select: Eventing between SAP Cloud Systems

    • Add the following systems in the Include Systems step of the wizard (IMPORTANT NOTE: All of them should be in the same BTP Subaccount):
      • Your registered SAP SuccessFactors system
      • The SAP Cloud Application Event Hub service (might also reflect as Event Broker)
      • Your SAP Build Process Automation tenant
    • Review the selection

    • Click Create and check that the formation is created successfully

Step 4: Add Integration Dependency

In the SAP BTP cockpit System Landscape, you need to define integration dependencies that describe the events you need to integrate with another system for a given scenario.

    •  Select the Formation created in the above step

Navigate to SAP Build Process Automation ‚Üí Open in System Page

    • Click Integration Dependencies  -> Add

    • Fill in:
      • Template

      • Name: e.g., SF_Eventing
      • Publishing System Namespace:sap.sf
      • Event Type: (paste exactly from SF docs)

    • Review and Add

Check that the Integration Dependency is added

 Step 5: Create Integration Formation

The formation type "Integration with SAP Build" refers to a configuration within SAP BTP (Business Technology Platform) that enables the integration of SAP systems with the SAP Build suite, specifically for scenarios like process automation and application development. This formation type is used when you want to connect your SAP system (e.g., SAP Success Factors) to services like SAP Build Process Automation or other SAP Build solutions. 

    • Navigate to Global Account ‚Üí System Landscape ‚Üí Formations -> Customer View -> Click Create Formation

    • Give a formation name and Select: Integration with SAP Build

    • Add the following systems in the Include Systems step of the wizard (IMPORTANT NOTE: All of them should be in the same BTP Subaccount):
      • Your registered SAP SuccessFactors system
      • Your SAP Build tenant
    • Review the selection

    •  Click Create and check that the formation is created successfully

Step 5: Validate in Event Hub App

As SAP Build is a consumer of events, you need manage event subscriptions in the SAP Cloud Application Event Hub application. Integration dependencies defined in the System Landscape become available as event subscriptions.

Pre-requisite : Assign relevant Event Broker Roles to your user, if roles were just assigned, re-login.

    • Open the Event Hub Application

 Click on ‚ÄúAll Available Subscriptions‚Äù and select the subscription name that we have created in the above step.

 Enable the SFSF event subscription.

Click on Enable.

Check that the Subscription status is ‚ÄúActive‚Äù.

Step 6: Create and publish an events project

Now you need to create an event project from the SAP Build Lobby which will be published to Library so that we can use it as an event trigger in the SBPA process. Follow the steps mentioned below:

  • Create an event project. Go to the SAP BTP Sub Account -> Lobby -> Connectors ->Events ->Create.

  • As the Success Factors system and BTP Subaccount are now connected and we will be able to choose events based on the connected systems, choose Unified Customer Landscape.

Note: Read Discovering Business Events from Lobby for SAP Build Process Automation : Manage Credit Memo Request for more ways to create Event Projects from SAP Build Lobby.

Select SAP SuccessFactors Onboarding Events.

Select Onboarding Process Step.

Review all the events and payloads and click on Add.

Create the event project. Release and publish it to the library. Note : Publishing is mandatory to be able to use the events as event trigger in any SBPA Process.

After the event project is created successfully, its listed in the Lobby.

Step 7: Create and Deploy a Sample process in SAP Build Process Automation

    • Go to SAP Build Process Automation from the BTP Subaccount
    • Create a new Process Project,  the empty process would look like the following.

    • Click on Add a trigger ->  ‚ÄúWait for an Event‚Äù from the trigger options to add an event trigger to the project.

  • Search and Add the required event from the library.

After creation of event trigger check that the event trigger is added and the Outputs tab shows the event payload.  This payload can be further used in the business process for further processing like approvals, decisions, subprocesses , actions etc.

    • Add a simple action (e.g., approval or email) or any set of actions required for your business process. A sample process could look like the following.

    • Release and Deploy the process by selecting appropriate environment.
    • Test by triggering the event from Success Factors.

The below step confirms that the Personal Data Collection is completed and this event should now trigger our deployed SBPA Process.

 Go to SAP BTP Subaccount -> Lobby -> Monitoring -> Process and Workflow Instances and check that the process is in Running status.

 You can open the process instance to see further details. For example, in the below logs the task is waiting to be approved in My Inbox.

 Click My Inbox to review and approve the task.

 Note that the simple approval process based on SuccessFactors event is completed.

 Below is the sample Logs view for the completed process instance.

Troubleshooting Tips

    • If systems aren‚Äôt showing in formations: double-check region/subaccount match
    • Event Hub app not showing dependencies? Check your user role + re-login
    • Not receiving events? Confirm SuccessFactors is emitting the specific event (some are tenant-configurable). Also check the section Lobby -> Monitoring -> Acquired Events -> Business Events to confirm that business events are received in SBPA.

Conclusion

You‚Äôve now connected SAP SuccessFactors to SAP Build via SAP Cloud Application Event Hub! This architecture lays the groundwork for robust, event-driven automations‚Äîlike onboarding workflows‚Äîall without writing complex integration code or going through complicated setup process.

References

Please refer to the below blogs for event driven architecture in SAP Build Process Automation:

Business Event Triggers in SAP Build Process Automation for SAP S/4HANA Cloud : The Customer Return (BKP) Use Case

Business Event Triggers in SAP Build Process Automation for SAP S/4HANA: Manage Billing Block on Sales Orders

Business Event Triggers in SAP Build Process Automation for SAP S/4HANA: Manage Credit Block on Sales Orders

Discovering Business Events from Lobby for SAP Build Process Automation : Manage Credit Memo Request

Event Mesh and SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud Setup for SAP Build Process Automation
Incorporating Custom Events from Lobby into SAP Build Process Automation

entry.title: Re: Improved Incoterm Handling in SAP TM
entry.content:
I am seeing a difference when dealing with Advance intercompany and additional stages are created for no reason. e.g. for Incoterm DAP, the expectation is only one source and destination, however system creates two stage.. For incoterms other than DAP, e.g. EXW or CIF etc.. it is creating one stage. The following are the steps:

1. We are using advanced intercompany STO process and we created a delivery for the STO, The location 1 is active and entered in PO which is carried to delivery.

2. The Transportation planning is active and respective freight units are generated for the deliveries

3. For all the incoterms the location is mandatory

4. The incoterm location stage building rule used is "Two active stage type 1" as default, but the behaviour is the same irrespective of the setting i.e. even using "Two active stage type 2" also behaves the same.

5. The issue is that the system behaves differently for DAP. For EXW, CIF there is only one stage created, however when Incoterms DAP is used, it creates two stages and both are blocked. The stages are between origin and incoterm location and then to destination.

6. The stage shows that the ownership changes between the plants at incoterm point

7. Since DAP is deliver at place, there should be only one stage created. For CIF, I was expecting more stages, but it does not. Not sure what is the issue.

entry.title: Re: Need Clarification on the Role of SAP CS in the Conte...
entry.content:
SAP SD covers standard order-to-cash processes‚Äîquotations, sales orders, delivery, invoicing‚Äîbut once you step into after-sales service (repairs, on-site maintenance, warranty handling), SD alone lacks the built-in workflows for notifications, service orders, warranty tracking or resource-related billing that a dedicated Customer Service solution provides. SAP CS integrates seamlessly with SAP PM and SAP SD to bridge that gap, combining maintenance planning with customer billing in one integrated module

SAP CS extends PM-style maintenance into the customer sphere by adding layers for service management and billing. Key CS capabilities include:

  • Service notifications for logging customer complaints and issues
  • Service orders to plan and execute on-site tasks with work centers and cost centers
  • Warranty and repair order processing, including returns and claims
  • Service contract management with SLAs, periodic billing, and contract renewals
  • Resource-related billing via the Dynamic Item Processor (DIP) to transfer maintenance costs into SD billing documents

Key scenarios where SAP CS is essential is whenever you perform paid maintenance on customer-owned equipment‚Äîor need formal SLAs, warranty coverage or time-and-material billing‚ÄîSAP CS is the right tool. By contrast, PM alone handles only internal assets (no billing) and SD alone requires heavy customization to manage service logistics. Typical CS scenarios include:

  • Field service on installed-base equipment at customer sites
  • Repairs under warranty or service agreements
  • Time-and-material or fixed-price billing for on-site visits
  • Service quotations and debit/credit memo requests based on service orders
  • Rental and leasing equipment maintenance with integrated billing

Using SAP CS in these cases avoids custom builds and leverages out-of-the-box processes designed for customer-facing service operation

Since you asked about real-world example, a turbine manufacturer sells units with annual maintenance contracts. When a pressure sensor fails at a customer site, a service notification in CS triggers a service order. Spare parts are reserved, a technician dispatched, work recorded, and final billing generated automatically against the contract‚Äîtracking hours, materials and warranty coverage. Trying to replicate that in pure SD would require custom status management, invoicing logic and resource planning; SAP CS delivers it end-to-end by design

entry.title: Configuration Localization Tool (CLT) now generally available with SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Ed. 2508
entry.content:
We‚Äôre excited to announce the general availability of the Configuration Localization Tool (CLT) with the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508 release ‚Äî now available for the 3-system landscape environment. This marks a significant milestone in empowering customers and partners to create and manage customer local versions at scale with greater flexibility and control.

The need for accelerating innovation due to rapidly changing products, business models, and services is amplified by M&A, new ventures, and divestitures of assets no longer considered core, and esp. by expansion into new markets ‚Äì SAP Cloud ERP  using the Configuration Localization Tool is an excellent foundation to tackle various complexities, be they in payments, tax management or financial reporting across diverse regulatory environments.

With the 2508 release, SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition now supports local versions for 60 countries/regions in 34 languages, to manage customers‚Äô business processes and still stay compliant by following country/region-specific regulations around accounting, taxes, payments, statutory reporting, electronic document processing. Refer to country/region-specific help for covered compliance.

For markets beyond these 60 SAP-delivered local versions, customers / partners can now build customer local versions on project basis for up to 160 countries/regions using the Configuration Localization Tool (CLT) and manage country/region-specific localization requirements with extensibility offered via Localization as a Self-Service for SAP S/4HANA Cloud - providing the flexibility needed to address market-specific requirements.

During our Early Adoption Program we saw strong customer interest; 86 customers are live with 78 unique customer local versions built in collaboration with 63 partners who also provide extensibility whenever required.

Pls. find an overview on CLT combined with PL (the Parallel Line) here

‚Ä¶and a story about the successful carve-out of Accelleron from its parent company (ABB), based on a common technology foundation, a global process model for 40 countries/regions, finalizing the separation within two years. Localization as a self-service played a key role to help keep the strict timeline and ability to build out 7 missing local version on project basis.

entry.title: üöÄBuilding Agents for a Simple Microservice Architecture with FastAPI (Part 2)
entry.content:
Previous Blog :  Building Collaborative Microservices in Python with FastAPI: Echo & Reverse Agents (Beginner -Part1)

Microservices are a powerful way to design scalable and maintainable applications.

In this blog, we will explore a minimal yet effective microservice setup using FastAPI, perfect for learning and experimentation. This will help to you build better Microservices and deploy in SAP BTP - Kyma

Sample Use Case

A client sends a city name to the Weather Agent. The agent fetches enrichment data from the Data Enricher, generates fake weather data, and returns a combined report. This mimics real-world API composition and data aggregation.

Overview

It consists of two core services:

  • Fake Weather Agent (weather_agent.py)
  • Data Enricher (data_enricher.py)

A shell script (run.sh) is included to launch both services on separate ports, simulating a real-world microservice environment.

üå¶Ô∏è 1. Fake Weather Agent (weather_agent.py)

Purpose:   Generates a fake weather report for a given city.

API Endpoint:  POST /weather ‚Äî Accepts a JSON payload with a city name.

How It Works:

  1. Receives a city name from the client.
  2. Optionally calls the Data Enricher service to fetch additional info (e.g., population, country).
  3. Generates random weather data:
    • Temperature
    • Condition (e.g., sunny, rainy)
    • Humidity
    • Wind speed
  4. Returns a combined weather report, enriched with city metadata if available.

Tech Stack:

  • FastAPI for API development
  • Pydantic for data validation
  • httpx for asynchronous HTTP calls
from fastapi import FastAPI, HTTPException
from pydantic import BaseModel
import httpx
import os
import random

PORT = int(os.getenv("PORT", 8002))
TARGET = os.getenv("TARGET_URL", "http://localhost:8003")   # downstream agent

app = FastAPI(title="Fake-Weather-Agent")

class Location(BaseModel):
    city: str

class WeatherReport(BaseModel):
    source: str
    city: str
    temperature: float   # ¬∞C
    condition: str
    humidity: int        # %
    wind_kmh: float

CONDITIONS = ["Sunny", "Cloudy", "Rain", "Snow", "Thunderstorm"]

@app.post("/weather", response_model=WeatherReport)
async def get_weather(loc: Location):
    """Generate a fake weather report for the given city."""
    # Optionally call another agent (e.g. a ‚Äúdata-enrichment‚Äù service)
    async with httpx.AsyncClient() as client:
        try:
            r = await client.post(
                f"{TARGET}/enrich",
                json={"city": loc.city}
            )
            r.raise_for_status()
            extra = r.json()
        except Exception:
            extra = {}

    return WeatherReport(
        source="Fake-Weather-Agent",
        city=loc.city,
        temperature=round(random.uniform(-10, 40), 1),
        condition=random.choice(CONDITIONS),
        humidity=random.randint(20, 95),
        wind_kmh=round(random.uniform(0, 40), 1),
        **extra
    )

üèôÔ∏è 2. Data Enricher (data_enricher.py)

Purpose: Provides additional metadata about a city.

API Endpoint: POST /enrich ‚Äî Accepts a JSON payload with a city name.

How It Works:

  1. Looks up the city in a fake in-memory database.
  2. Returns population and country if found.
  3. If not found, returns default placeholder values.

Tech Stack:

  • FastAPI
  • Pydantic
from fastapi import FastAPI
from pydantic import BaseModel

app = FastAPI(title="Data-Enricher")

class EnrichRequest(BaseModel):
    city: str

class EnrichResponse(BaseModel):
    population: int
    country: str

FAKE_DB = {
    "london": {"population": 9_000_000, "country": "UK"},
    "paris":  {"population": 2_100_000, "country": "France"},
    "tokyo":  {"population": 14_000_000, "country": "Japan"},
}

@app.post("/enrich", response_model=EnrichResponse)
def enrich(req: EnrichRequest):
    city = req.city.lower()
    if city not in FAKE_DB:
        return EnrichResponse(population=0, country="Unknown")
    return FAKE_DB[city]

üñ•Ô∏è 3. Running the Services (run.sh)

Purpose: Starts both services using uvicorn, FastAPI‚Äôs ASGI server.
A shell script (run.sh) is provided to run both services on different ports.

How It Works:

  • Launches Fake Weather Agent on port 8002
  • Launches Data Enricher on port 8003
  • Each service runs in its own terminal window
# Terminal 1
uvicorn fake_weather:app --port 8002 --reload

# Terminal 2
uvicorn data_enricher:app --port 8003 --reload

Key Points : 

  • Microservice Communication:
    The Weather Agent calls the Data Enricher via HTTP to demonstrate service-to-service communication.
  • Extensibility:
    Easy to add more enrichment services or expand the fake database.
  • FastAPI Features:
    Shows how to use Pydantic models, async endpoints, and response models.
  • Local Development:  
    Simple to run both services locally for testing and learning.

entry.title: Re: How can i change batch in EWM outbound Delivery if th...
entry.content:
In decentralized EWM, once your ERP outbound delivery has been distributed and the warehouse task (WT) created, the system ‚Äúlocks in‚Äù the batch on the WT. If you try to pick a different batch at confirmation without the proper exception‚Äêcode setup, you‚Äôll get a ‚Äúyou can‚Äôt change the batch‚Äù message. Likewise, you cannot manually insert a batch-split subitem‚Äîthose only come from the system‚Äôs own split logic.

To let your RF/desktop pickers switch to a valid warehouse batch on the fly, you must:

  • Configure the CHBA exception code in EWM
  • Assign it to the Confirm Warehouse Task context and step
  • Train users to enter CHBA at confirmation and supply the new batch

Below are the detailed steps.

Define and Assign the CHBA Exception Code

  • In the EWM system launch SPRO ‚Üí SAP Reference IMG ‚Üí Extended Warehouse Management ‚Üí Cross‚ÄêProcess Settings ‚Üí RF Framework ‚Üí Define Exception Codes.
  • Create or verify code CHBA (‚ÄúChange Batch‚Äù) with a meaningful description.
  • Go back in IMG to Assign Exception Codes to Business Contexts.
  • Select Business Context TPI (‚ÄúConfirm Warehouse Task ‚Äì Stock Removal‚Äù).
  • Assign CHBA to the Internal Step for RF (usually step 05) and/or desktop (step 02). Save and transport.

Test in RF or Desktop Confirmation

  • Create or pick up your Outbound Delivery in EWM so that a WT is generated.
  • On your RF device or desktop screen for Warehouse Order Confirmation:

At the ‚ÄúBatch‚Äù input you‚Äôll see the proposed batch. Enter exception code CHBA. The system will prompt you for a new batch number. Enter one that actually exists in your warehouse and continue confirmation

Why manual batch splits fail is because, Batch-split subitems in an ERP delivery are generated by the decentralized WMS when multiple batches fill a single WT line. You cannot manually add a split item in ERP (VL02N) or in EWM‚Äîonly the system can. The only ‚Äúuser-driven‚Äù change at pick time is via an exception code (CHBA).

entry.title: Re: Preferential origin not determined on invoice
entry.content:
When you bill from plant 1001 but produce in plant 1004, SAP GTS by default evaluates origin based on the plant of the billing document. If you haven‚Äôt turned on cross-plant BOM evaluation and document transfer for that billing doc, GTS never ‚Äúsees‚Äù the BOM or threshold from plant 1004 and thus cannot confirm preference. The result is VBRP-PREFE stays blank and the invoice print shows ‚ÄúNo.‚Äù

How Preference Determination works in GTS is that

  • SAP ECC transfers fixed BOMs and configurable BOMs from the feeder system to GTS based on your ‚ÄúControl Transfer of Bills of Product‚Äù settings. GTS uses these BOMs to compute a minimum value (threshold) for each component and the finished product.
  • When a billing document is created and sent to GTS, GTS runs preference determination, comparing the net item value against the product‚Äôs threshold. If value ‚â• threshold, preferential origin is confirmed, and GTS marks the item with a preference indicator (I_PRECD).

Finally, GTS sends the preference flag back to ECC, updating VBRP-PREFE. You must implement SAP Notes 379269 and 829932 to enable this round-trip flag transfer.

Why Plant 1001 saw ‚ÄúNo‚Äù while Plant 1004 should qualify is because

  • By default, GTS evaluates BOMs and thresholds for the plant that owns the billing doc (1001). If no BOM or threshold is maintained for plant 1001, GTS cannot determine origin and leaves the flag blank.
  • You need GTS to ‚Äúlook into‚Äù plant 1004‚Äôs BOM and threshold when shipping from plant 1001. That requires cross-plant BOM evaluation in your preference model.

Configuration Steps to Confirm Preferential Origin Across Plants

  • Define a Plant Group and Cross-Plant Preference Model SPRO ‚Üí SAP Global Trade Services ‚Üí General Settings ‚Üí Organizational Structures. ‚ÄúDefine Plant-Based BOM Evaluation‚Äù for single-plant checks. ‚ÄúDefine Cross-Plant BOM Evaluation‚Äù: group plants 1001 & 1004 under one group so GTS evaluates the highest threshold among them
  • Ensure BOMs for Plant 1004 Are Transferred SPRO ‚Üí Sales and Distribution ‚Üí Foreign Trade/Customs ‚Üí SAP GTS Plug-In ‚Üí Control Data for Transfer to SAP GTS. In ‚ÄúControl Transfer of Bills of Product for Preference and Re-Export,‚Äù activate static BOM transfer for your materials and include plant 1004
  • Activate Invoice Transfer to GTS SPRO ‚Üí Sales and Distribution ‚Üí Foreign Trade/Customs ‚Üí SAP GTS Plug-In ‚Üí Control Data for Transfer to SAP GTS ‚Üí Control Transfer of Documents. Add your billing types (e.g., F2) so that each invoice (99148879) is sent to GTS for preference determination
  • Implement Preference Indicator Return Apply SAP Notes 379269 and 829932 (if required) to enable GTS to write back the ‚ÄúX‚Äù into ECC‚Äôs VBRP-PREFE field upon completion of determination

entry.title: A little glance at S/4 Hana OUTPUT MANAGEMENT and compare its to our old friend NAST
entry.content:
As we already know, NAST output has been used over time, from ECC to S4/HANA, due to its reliability and its customization. Based on NAST, we could generate tons of outputs with different types, from simple PDF form or Adobe form to more complex output like EDI/IDOC or even XML.

However, Output management is introduced in S/4 HANA as S/4 HANA OUTPUT MANAGEMENT, as more ‚Äúcentralized‚Äù approach to output, based on BRF+ (business rule framework). FYI, BRF+ has been on SAP from ECC, which supported users specific customizations, based on the role, but applying this for S/4 HANA output management is new thing. Using S/4 HANA Output Management is a less-coding approach, compares to NAST, when you need to do bunches of customizations, which is prefer for consultants than end users.

For short, you can check out this table from our friend :

S/4HANA Output Management vs. NAST: When to Choose... - SAP Community

 

Technology

BRF+

SAPscript / Smart Forms

Customization Flexibility

Limited by service nodes

Customizable to your heart‚Äôs content

Form Type

Adobe Forms

SAPscript, Smart Forms

Output Types

Print, Email, XML, EDI

Print, Email, Fax, EDI

Multiple Outputs per Document

BRF+ (but expect headaches)

Easier management with condition records

Learning Curve

Steep‚Äîbetter grab some coffee 

Familiar, like catching up with an old friend

Centralized Management

Yes‚Äîstreamlined oversight

Traditional, less streamlined

Future-Proofing

Yes‚Äîleverages the latest technology

No‚Äîlegacy technology means potential obsolescence

Recommended Use Case

Standard scenarios, new systems

Custom-heavy projects, legacy systems

For short, we can understand that, using NAST is like our reliable, multi functional car that can ramp up anything, just look not really good, but Output Management is introduced as sport cars, like a F1 Mercedes AMG W16, that could only drive on an F1 track.

The purpose of this blog is not to deep dive on theoretical questions how better or how worse of each method, but to know how the configuration of output management, is it much easier than a NAST approach?

Let I guide you steps by steps

HOW SETUP OF OUTPUT MANAGEMENT

To check out our Output Management,  lets come to our SPRO -> Cross-Application Components -> Output Control

As we can see, there are bunches of configurations, that are very easy to recognize than our NACE t-code setup. As we know, NACE t-code is follow  based on our condition technique setup, which it takes the combinations of key index and cross-check the condition record, then the medium things and routine things follow up.

Lets look how can activate the Output Management before NAST

Next step, we can go to Define Output Types




As we can see, for each Object Types, Output Management support not only different ranges of Output Type but also the variance of the Output, which is different approach from NAST.  

Let‚Äôs take the Change for example. In NAST, we can retrigger the old output by in case of changes. The same output will be trigger once again when we hit save on the document. But for the Output Management, we could have our own ‚Äúchanges‚Äù output here.

Let‚Äôs check this output type for ‚ÄúCash Sales Changes‚Äù as below



Double click on the Callback Class.

As we can see just one type of Output, we can see the API information or type of forms/mediums that the output can support in this case

Next step, as we remember from our Friend NAST, in order to generate an output , we need to know which medium (EDI, Printer, Email, Tax).. For each type of output, if you remember, we have this screen in NACE:



For Output Management, we follow BRF+ (Business Rule Framework), so we do not follow Condition Technique.

So it means that for each output type, you have different means of Channel (or Medium if you are in NACE/NAST). Each Output type has their own channel, and each output type has their own form templates or their own email templates. We can check at detail at ‚ÄúAssign Form Template‚Äù or ‚ÄùAssign Email Template‚Äù

Enough for the setup, let‚Äôs get to the most important part of our Output Management.

instead of Output procedure or condition technique we have to deal with, Output management with the help of BRF+, use the ‚ÄúBusiness Rules for Output Determination‚Äù

As you can see, since its not follow the Condition Technique, Output Management helps user to setup the rule with friendly UI. However, for me Condition Technique is less complex than, because it is used not only for Output but also for Pricing for Sales, Pricing for Purchasing or Tax Determination (just my 2 cents).

Let‚Äôs get back to our Business rule:

For Output type, we can input the combinations we like (of course base on the table related to the situations, again, more user-friendly, less consultant-friendly (your pick)

For other‚Äôs determination, these can base on the same rule for Receiver, Printer Settings, etc. Just the same as Condition Record, but at more ‚Äúuser-friendly‚Äù

After all the setup, get back to how our Output type working in Transactional situation, in this case is the Purchase Order:

As you can see, when we activate the Output Management, the old screen of NAST is no longer, instead, its now generate new type of screen. In this screen, we input PRINT ‚Äúchannel‚Äù as our medium in this case. Click on line, choose button ‚ÄùDisplay Details‚Äù:

Or we can look over if we use ‚ÄúEMAIL‚Äù channel, you can easily put CC or BCC for email address

CONCLUSIONS

As we can see how easily that users can access to their output and adjust their output with just simple modifications, even add emails for CC or BCC purposes. However, we also see that how frustration Output Management can bring out whenever if we want to have new type of forms, or any new heavy-customized oriented conditions, while NAST can provide us with just few clicks.  So we surely know that S/4 Hana Output Management could be used in the situations that are more centralized, more " basic" and less "complicated", while our NAST could be trustworthy at all the time, but both of them are solutions to different scenarios so don't just stick to only one. Be flexible within the situation.

entry.title: Re: Able to Schedule Dates on Weekends (Make Parts - MRP...
entry.content:
You‚Äôve nailed your factory calendar, work‚Äêcenter calendar, and shift sequence‚Äîall show capacity on Saturdays and Sundays. To get both production orders and MRP planned orders to actually land on weekends, you must align two additional ‚Äúdate engines‚Äù in SAP: the MRP Planning Calendar (for period‚Äêlot sizing) and your order‚Äêscheduling logic (margin keys and OPU parameters).

  • How MRP dates are calculated is that with lot‚Äêfor‚Äêlot (EX) or reorder‚Äêpoint (VB) sizing, MRP uses net‚Äêrequirement or reorder‚Äêrun dates plus lead times, then applies the Factory Calendar. Since yours is 7-day, EX orders will fall on weekends only if the demand date itself is a weekend.
  • With Period Lot Size (PK), MRP groups requirements into planning‚Äêcalendar periods and dates planned orders on the period boundary. This uses a separate Planning Calendar, not the factory calendar.
  • Create a Planning Calendar (SPRO ‚Üí Production ‚Üí Material Requirements Planning ‚Üí Master Data ‚Üí Define Planning Calendar). Give it an ID (e.g. Z7DAYS), validity covering your horizon. Mark Mon‚ÄìSun as working days.
  • Or use transaction MD25 to build Z7DAYS. Calculation rule = Daily (or Weekly with daily periods). Flag every day as working
  • Assign to the Material (MM02 ‚Üí MRP 2 view). Lot‚Äêsize procedure = PK. Planning calendar = Z7DAYS

With this in place, MRP will date planned orders on weekends whenever period boundaries (or net requirements, if EX) fall there.

Your production scheduling engine relies on:

  • Work Center calendar (7-day)
  • Shift sequence (includes weekend shifts)
  • Routing operation durations
  • Scheduling margin key (float before/after)

Check the Scheduling Margin Key in SPRO ‚Üí Production ‚Üí Production Scheduling ‚Üí Scheduling ‚Üí Maintain Scheduling Margin Keys

Select your key (e.g. ‚Äú01‚Äù). Ensure Floats Before/After are set as needed. No indicator forcing ‚Äúearliest start = next working day‚Äù

Margin keys don‚Äôt themselves skip non-working days‚Äîthey defer to the calendar on your work center. With your WC calendar open on weekends, operations will schedule there.

Finally, OPU3 (planned orders) and OPU5 (production orders) determine forward/backward scheduling logic. Make sure they reference your weekend‚Äêenabled work center and do not override the calendar with fixed‚Äêdate flags

entry.title: PCo fundamentals
entry.content:
Dear Experts,

I recently started learning PCo and have some basic questions that I haven't been able to find answers to.

My configuration is as follows:
PCo version 15.5.
Source: Socket Source System with multiple connections.
Destination: RFC to ECC.

I have an agent with the SAP NW RFC Server configured (Program ID: PCO_RFC_AGENT) and a notification with an "Always" trigger. On the ECC side, I have a single RFC destination. I am able to receive the message in SAP via the RFC function module S_PCO_RFC_EXECUTE_RECEIVE_EVNT. All notifications are sent with the same application handle PCO_NOTIFY. After XML data extraction I get "1 W01_9311 xsd:string S S -0.23380 kg# None", where W01_9311 is the socket connection name (can be used as an ID) 

The setup for this scenario is well documented, but I still have some fundamental questions:

  1. In my case, socket with multiple connections, each notification must trigger a different function module. How can I achieve this?
  2. When using multiple agents with the same RFC destination, notifications still need to trigger different functions modules.

<mvc:View

                        <template>
                            <m:CheckBox/>

                    </Column>

        </m:content>
    </m:Page>
</mvc:View>

entry.title: Re: In the context of Production Planning Integration, NB...
entry.content:
Hi @thiago-araujo 

Following up on your question about your Production Planning Integration, here is what i think is probably happening and what should check to pinpoint the issue

Based on the information you provided, the issue potential highlights that the system is not correctly assigning order numbers to the planned orders during the integration process. That issue is often caused by either missing or misconfigured number ranges for your order types in S/4HANA.

It is important to note that when the order number is "0000000000," the system treats each new order as the same one, resulting in replacement rather than multiple unique orders that might be the target in this case.

I recommend you try the evaluate the following:

First, make sure to review the configuration for planned order types and make sure that number ranges are correctly defined and available in your S/4HANA backend.

Then, once you have confirmed that the number ranges are set up correctly, run the integration again to confirm that orders are now assigned to the proper numbers and each IBP execution results in unique orders.

Should the problem persist, enable detailed logs or tracing on the PP-DS order creation, and consider reaching out to SAP support with all findings and a reference to your applied SAP notes.

 

I hope this helps you solve the issue. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

If you find my response helpful, kindly accept the answer and award a Kudos to this post. Your support is appreciated.

Best regards

Chris

 

 

Managing Planned Orders in SAP S/4HANA

entry.title: Re: Unexpected Behavior with Team Filter in Peform Mainte...
entry.content:
Hi @MarieMor 

Thank you for the details and your hypothesis. I will walk you through my understanding.

Haven evaluated the details provided; I reviewed your question and can share the potential cause of the issues you are facing.

First, note that when you define a team in the type MAINT_TEAM app, this only drives job filtering if there you have directly assigned users as team members to that specific work centre‚Äôs team.

Also note that currently there is no automatic link from MAINT_TEAM to HR objects unless you explicitly add the person or their role as a member in the team definition as desired.

Following on that, when HR assignments are made directly to the work center, the jobs appear because those assignments are already recognized in responsibility determination.

Finally, without either personalization or explicit person-to-team assignment, the filter will not return results.

This is what i suggest you should do:

It is important to ensure that each of the intended user is added as a team member in the relevant work center team.

Once that is done, confirm the team is linked to the correct work center.

You do not require any extra HR mapping step but the user must explicitly exist in the team for filtering to work.

The summary is, MAINT_TEAM is not implicitly tied to HR data, and the job filter will work without HR assignments only if the users are directly assigned in the team setup for that work center.

I hope this helps you solve the issue. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

If you find my response helpful, kindly accept the answer and award a Kudos to this post. Your support is appreciated.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Autosubmission of empty timesheets
entry.content:
Hi @ManonH 

Regarding your question about empty timesheets not being auto submitted when no overtime is recorded, please note that by design, SAP‚Äôs Time Sheet Submit job will only process timesheets with recorded entries or generated external time data. If your timesheet is fully empty and untouched, no external data is generated and therefore will be skipped by the job.

Please note, when you edit your desired timesheet and delete entries, this creates external data that triggers submission even if it is empty afterward.

For you to be able to carry out auto submission of untouched empty timesheets, you will need to configure the desired Time Sheet Submission Rules assigned to your overtime recorders that defines this behaviour or you can make use of the Time Recording Calendar to trigger submissions on defined schedules.

Finally, make sure that there are no pending approvals or errors that block submission.

I hope this helps you solve the issue. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

If you find my response helpful, kindly accept the answer and award a Kudos to this post. Your support is appreciated.

Best regards

Chris

2738965 - Time Sheet Automatic Submission and Workflow Processing Behavior

Automatic Submission of Time Sheets

entry.title: Re: Integrating 3PL REST API with SAP Public Cloud (1ZQ S...
entry.content:
Hi @mbesli33 

Thank you for your question. Haven read through your details, there are a few key points that I would like to highlight.

Please note that the scope item 1ZQ in the Public Cloud is currently delivered with SOAP-based communication arrangements and message structures which is done via WSDL. It does not have a native mechanism to consume a REST API directly.

Also, SAP‚Äôs Public Cloud does not provide any in‚Äësystem message transformation or REST‚ÜîSOAP protocol mediation. Based on information, this was done by design to ensure and preserve the clean core approach and avoid embedded middleware.

However, note that custom APIs can expose new OData or REST endpoints but they will not transform any existing standard SOAP interfaces for 1ZQ.

Based on those details it is clear that without Integration Suite, your only technical options are to:

First, have the 3PL adapt their interface to expose a SOAP service.

Then to introduce a lightweight external transformation service to handle the REST‚ÜîSOAP mapping and field‚Äëlevel conversions before you call the S/4HANA Public Cloud.

Be aware that any field or structure mapping will need to happen in that external layer or on the 3PL side. There is currently no configuration‚Äëonly way in Public Cloud to remap payloads for the standard 1ZQ SOAP service.

That brings me to my recommendation; If avoiding middleware entirely is mandatory for you, the most feasible route is to work with the 3PL to match SAP‚Äôs standard SOAP schema. If limited external services are possible, a small cloud-hosted adapter can help you bridge REST and SOAP without a full middleware platform.

I hope this helps you solve the issue. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

If you find my response helpful, kindly accept the answer and award a Kudos to this post. Your support is appreciated.

Best regards

Chris

 

Building and Publishing External APIs in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public: From ADT to Postman
